title:
Fate and impact of organics in an immersed membrane bioreactor applied to brine
denitrification and ion exchange regeneration
abstract:
The application of membrane bioreactors (MBRs) to brine denitrification for ion
exchange regeneration has been studied. The developed culture was capable of
complete brine denitrification at 50 gNaCl.l−1. Denitrification reduced to c.60%
and c.70% when salinity was respectively increased to 75 and 100 g.l−1, presumed
to be due to reduced growth rate and the low imposed solids retention time (10
days). Polysaccharide secretion was not induced by stressed cells following salt
shocking, implying that cell lysis did not occur. Fouling propensity, monitored
by critical flux, was steady at 12–15 l.m−2.h−1 during salinity shocking and
after brine recirculation, indicating that the system was stable following
perturbation. Low molecular weight polysaccharide physically adsorbed onto the
nitrate selective anion exchange resin during regeneration reducing exchange
capacity by c.6.5% when operating up to complete exhaustion. However, based on a
breakthrough threshold of 10 mgNO3−-N.l−1 the exchange capacity was comparative
to that determined when using freshly produced brine for regeneration. It was
concluded that a denitrification MBR was an appropriate technology for IEX spent
brine reco

Accepted Manuscript
Title: Fate and impact of organics in an immersed membrane bioreactor applied to
brine denitrification and ion exchange regeneration
Authors: Ewan J. McAdam, Mark Pawlett, Simon J. Judd
PII: S0043-1354(09)00564-8
DOI: 10.1016/j.watres.2009.08.048
Reference: WR 7610
To appear in: Water Research
Received Date: 18 March 2009
Revised Date: 17 August 2009
Accepted Date: 30 August 2009
Please cite this article as: McAdam, E.J., Pawlett, M., Judd, S.J. Fate and impact of organics in an
immersed membrane bioreactor applied to brine denitrification and ion exchange regeneration, Water
Research (2009), doi: 10.1016/j.watres.2009.08.048

1 
 
Fate and impact of organics in an immersed membrane bioreactor applied to 1 
brine denitrification and ion exchange regeneration 2 
Ewan J. McAdam1, Mark Pawlett2, Simon J. Judd1 3 
1Centre for Water Science, Cranfield University, Bedfordshire, MK43 0AL 4 
2Natural Resources Department, Cranfield University, Bedfordshire, MK43 0AL 5 
 6 
ABSTRACT 7 
The application of membrane bioreactors (MBRs) to brine denitrification for ion 8 
exchange regeneration has been studied. The developed culture was capable of 9 
complete brine denitrification at 50 gNaCl.l-1. Denitrification reduced to c.60% and 10 
c.70% when salinity was respectively increased to 75 and 100 g.l-1, presumed to be 11 
due to reduced growth rate and the low imposed solids retention time (10 days). 12 
Polysaccharide secretion was not induced by stressed cells following salt shocking, 13 
implying that cell lysis did not occur. Fouling propensity, monitored by critical flux, 14 
was steady at 12-15 l.m-2.h-1 during salinity shocking and after brine recirculation, 15 
indicating that the system was stable following perturbation. Low molecular weight 16 
polysaccharide physically adsorbed onto the nitrate selective anion exchange resin 17 
during regeneration reducing exchange capacity by c.6.5% when operating up to 18 
complete exhaustion. However, based on a breakthrough threshold of 10 mgNO3--N.l-19 
1 the exchange capacity was comparative to that determined when using freshly 20 
produced brine for regeneration. It was concluded that a denitrification MBR was an 21 
appropriate technology for IEX spent brine recovery and reuse. 22 
 23 
Keywords: Ion-exchange; brine; biological denitrification; salt; nitrate 24 
 25 
 26 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
2 
 
1. INTRODUCTION 27 
Anion-exchange (aIEX) is the most frequently adopted technology for nitrate (NO3-) 28 
removal during potable water treatment due to its low cost and operational simplicity. 29 
A strong salt (NaCl) solution is used to regenerate the resin resulting in the production 30 
of concentrated waste brine containing the target anion, chloride and other oxyanions. 31 
This waste stream can comprise 0.8 to 2.4% of treated product flow (McAdam and 32 
Judd, 2008) and its disposal (usually by tankering) constitutes a significant proportion 33 
of the process cost.  Operation of aIEX in combination with biological nitrate 34 
reduction of the waste brine for regenerant recovery presents a more sustainable 35 
alternative by reducing the waste volume, salt (NaCl) consumption and treated 36 
product losses. 37 
 38 
Studies adapting non-halophilic microbial communities from standard activated 39 
sludge processes for this application have reported inhibition of denitrification and, in 40 
some cases, plasmolysis to be promoted by the elevated salt concentrations 41 
(>30gNaCl.l-1). More recently, halophilic monocultures Halomonas denitrificans 42 
(Cyplik et al., 2007) and Halomonas campisalis (Peyton et al., 2001) have been 43 
successfully adapted at laboratory scale for denitrification at high salt concentrations 44 
from 30 to 180 g.l-1, obviating dilution prior to biotreatment. However, adaptation of 45 
halophiles to brine processing is yet to be examined in detail.  46 
 47 
Other restrictions to this application include the accumulation of inorganic 48 
constituents (e.g. sulphate) due to recirculation, and the impact of organics and 49 
microbial carryover from the bioreactor on downstream resin regeneration. In brine 50 
re-use trials, elevated sulphate concentrations were not reported to impact upon either 51 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
3 
 
resin or biological performance when nitrate selective resins have been used (Clifford 52 
and Liu, 1993). However, Bae et al. (2002) reported that microbial associated 53 
particulates and organics present in the regenerant fouled anion exchange resins, thus 54 
the integration of both sand filtration and GAC were required downstream of the 55 
denitrification reactor to nullify the impact. Though little information exists on the 56 
impact of residual organics on resin capacity, the application of “classical” biomass 57 
separation membrane bioreactor (MBR) technology to this duty has been mooted to 58 
provide absolute bacterial rejection and high MW biopolymer retention, promoting a 59 
consistent permeate quality (McAdam and Judd, 2008).                    60 
 61 
The current paper assesses the viability of a denitrification MBR for waste aIEX brine 62 
treatment and reuse in the regeneration of ion exchange resins, specifically this study 63 
will address: the fate of organics during permeate brine recirculation (to simulate re-64 
use); the impact of organics on resin capacity; the influence of salt variation on 65 
halophilic treatment performance; and the impact of perturbation on fouling 66 
propensity. 67 
 68 
2. MATERIAL AND METHODS 69 
2.1 Experimental rig 70 
To establish a salt tolerant bacterial community, a seed culture was harvested from the 71 
anaerobic layer of a coastal sediment at low tide. Following acclimation in batch 72 
conditions (50 gNaCl.l-1, 500 mgNO3--N.l-1), a 75 l reactor (Figure 1) was seeded at a 73 
v/v ratio of 15:1. The influent nitrate concentration was set at 500 mg NO3--N.l-1. 74 
During substrate optimisation, ethanol was supplied as the exogenous substrate and 75 
dosed at a C:N ratio of between 0.77:1 and 8.5:1 (g.g-1); under normal conditions, a 76 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
4 
 
C:N of 0.85:1 was used. Reactor temperature was maintained at c.20ºC using a 77 
thermostatically controlled heating jacket. An impeller mixer was used to ensure 78 
complete biomass distribution with the impeller blade sited below the membrane 79 
module. The hydraulic and solids residence times (HRT and SRT respectively) were 80 
17.5 hours and 10 days respectively. The process was allowed 3 SRTs to acclimatise 81 
prior to testing. During recirculation experiments, MBR permeate was collected in a 82 
holding tank (T2), supplemented with NO3- and pumped back to the feed tank (T1). 83 
During salt upshocking/ downshocking experiments, the NaCl concentrate dosed into 84 
T1 was changed to meet the required concentration providing an incremental spike; 85 
fluid residence time in T1 was approximately 20 hours.   86 
 87 
A 0.93 m2 out-to-in immersed PVDF hollow-fibre membrane with 0.04 µm nominal 88 
pore size was used. Permeate was withdrawn under suction from the membrane using 89 
a piston pump (FMI Inc., Syosset, US). To maintain anoxic conditions, nitrogen-90 
enriched air (>99%) was used to scour the membrane. Gas was introduced via a 91 
solenoid valve (Zoedale Plc, Bedford, UK) and controlled with a programmable 92 
digital relay (Kübler Gmbh, Ludwigshafen, Germany); flow rate was controlled with 93 
a 0-50 l min-1 needle valve (RS Ltd., Corby, UK). Pressure was monitored using a -94 
0.5 to 0.5 barg calibrated pressure transducer (Gem Sensors, Basingstoke, UK) and 95 
data recorded using a 16-bit 0 to 2.5 V data conversion unit (Pico technology, St. 96 
Neots, UK). 97 
 98 
2.2 Anion exchange resin 99 
A commercially available nitrate selective macroporous styrene based anion exchange 100 
resin (Purolite A520E, Llantrisant, UK) was loaded into a 50mm diameter x 1m glass 101 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
5 
 
chromatography column and retained using 25 µm-rated frits at either end; the bed 102 
comprised 120g of resin. After initial rinsing, the A520E resin size ranged from 0.28 103 
to 1.26 mm (d50 0.61 mm).  Prior to use, DI water was pumped through the resin bed 104 
at 20 bed volumes (Bv).h-1 for 30 minutes, followed by a 30 minute 50gNaCl.l-1 flush 105 
(to ensure saturation) at 5 Bv.h-1 and a subsequent DI rinse for 60 minutes at 5 Bv.h-1. 106 
The exhaustion flow rate was set to 20 Bv.h-1 and the IEX feed contained 30 mgSO42-107 
.l-1, 115 mgCl-.l-1, 150 mgCaCO3.l-1 and 22.6 mg.l-1 NO3--N. Regeneration comprised 108 
a 60 minute cycle at 5 Bv.h-1 followed by slow and fast rinses of 5 Bv.h-1 for 30 109 
minutes and 20 Bv.h-1 for 10 minutes respectively.    110 
 111 
2.3 Chemical analysis 112 
2.3.1 General analysis 113 
Mixed liquor suspended solids (MLSS) and bicarbonate were determined by standard 114 
methods. Oxyanion (NO3-, NO2-) and chloride concentration was measured using 115 
proprietary cell tests (Merck Spectroquant) with spectrophotometric detection. 116 
Dissolved organic carbon (DOC) was measured using a Shimadzu TOC-5000A 117 
analyser. Ethanol concentration was determined using a commercially available 118 
enzymatic method (Boehringer-Mannheim, Roche). Soluble microbial products 119 
(SMP) were extracted according to the method described in Judd (2006) and 120 
polysaccharide and protein concentration quantified using the phenol–sulphuric acid 121 
method (Zhang et al., 1999) and modified Lowry method (Frølund et al., 1995) 122 
respectively. Absorbance for polysaccharide and protein determinations was 123 
measured using a Jenway 6505 UV/Vis spectrophotometer at UV480nm and UV750nm 124 
respectively with D-glucose and bovine serum albumin (BSA) as standards. Particle 125 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
6 
 
size distribution was measured with an integrated laser diffractor (Malvern 126 
Mastersizer 2000).  127 
 128 
2.3.2 Molecular weight fractionation 129 
Serial fractionation was undertaken using an Amicon 8400 series stirred cell, 130 
pressurised with N2 (1 barg), and standard UF (Millipore) membranes, size range 10, 131 
30, 50, 100 and 300kDa. Sample supernatant was pre-filtered using a 1.2µm filter and 132 
the subsequent sample split between two 300 kDa membranes to limit concentration 133 
polarisation. Concentration polarisation was limited by application of an integrated 134 
bar stirrer operate at a constant 100 rpm; the adopted filtrate/ retentate ratio was 0.4.  135 
 136 
2.3.3 Phospholipid fatty acid analysis 137 
Phospholipid fatty acid (PLFA) analysis was used to assess the community structure 138 
using the method of Frostegård et al. (1991). Samples were freeze dried prior to 139 
analysis. Lipids were extracted from the freeze dried sample using the Bligh and Dyer 140 
(1959) ratio of 1:2:0.8 (v/v/v) of chloroform, methanol and citrate buffer. Lipids were 141 
then fractionated by solid phase extraction. The phospholipid fraction was derivatised 142 
by mild alkaline methanolysis (Dowling et al., 1986). The resultant fatty-acid methyl 143 
esters (FAMES) were analyzed by GC-FID (Agilent). Peak identification was 144 
undertaken using GC-MS (Agilent). 145 
 146 
3. RESULTS 147 
3.1 Exogenous and endogenous organics transmission at steady state 148 
Nitrate removal efficiency increased from 84.6% to a maximum 99.8% as the carbon 149 
to nitrogen ratio (C:N) increased from 0.77 to 0.94 (Figure 2). Once a C:N ratio of 150 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
7 
 
0.89 had been exceeded, ethanol was detected in the permeate above the limit of 151 
detection (>0.5 mg l-1). Although the existence of an optimum C:N has been reported 152 
previously (McAdam et al., 2007), research studies typically observe low NO2--N and 153 
NO3--N effluent concentrations as the optimum C:N is exceeded due to the surplus of 154 
available carbon (Chiu and Chung, 2003; McAdam et al., 2007). In this study, on 155 
increasing C:N >0.98 inhibition was observed resulting in 71-97% of the available 156 
NO3- being converted to NO2- for C:N values up to 8.5. Yoshie et al. (2006) also 157 
reported nitrite accumulation in concentrated brines indicating reductase activity 158 
maybe very different at high salinity. 159 
 160 
Protein and polysaccharide transmission through the membrane at steady state were 161 
27.3%±8.0% and 81.5%±10.5% respectively. Fawehinmi (2006) observed similar 162 
transmission rates for proteins and polysaccharides, recording 49% and 80% 163 
respectively, for operation of an anaerobic immersed hollow fibre (0.1 µm) MBR. In 164 
this study, SMP exhibited a principal protein peak of 55.1% between <1.2 µm and 165 
300 kDa and a principal polysaccharide peak of 48.3% below 10 kDa (Figure 3). 166 
Organics between 1.2 μm and 100 kDa were absent in the permeate indicating the 167 
molecular weight cut off (MWCO) of the hollow-fibre (and any associated biofilm) 168 
was c.50 to 100 kDa. 169 
 170 
3.2 Impact of organics accumulation during recirculation 171 
After 7 days recirculation, the SMP DOC had increased from an initial concentration 172 
of c.170 mgDOC.l-1 (c.34 mgDOC.gMLSS-1) up to a maximum concentration of 557 173 
mgDOC.l-1 (Figure 4). At steady state, DOC transmission was recorded between 54% 174 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
8 
 
and 80% and was attributed to accumulation of low molecular weight (MW) organics 175 
(below the membrane MWCO).  176 
 177 
Critical flux analysis (Jc) was conducted using the flux step method before 178 
recirculation and after reaching steady state (Figure 5). In both cases, Jc was between 179 
12 and 15 l.m-2.h-1. Interestingly, similar exponential dP/dt trends were obtained for 180 
both sets of conditions, evidenced by similar gradients ((dP/dt)/J) of between 0.23 and 181 
0.27, however, dP/dt measured post-recirculation exhibited lower overall fouling 182 
potential. This appears counter-intuitive, based on the presence of accumulated 183 
organics and challenges previous reports which link fouling propensity to elevated 184 
concentrations of biopolymers in the bulk phase (Judd, 2006; Reid et al., 2006).  185 
 186 
3.3 IEX Resin capacity 187 
To allow comparison with previous aIEX resin studies (Clifford and Liu, 1993; Bae et 188 
al., 2002), NO3--N breakthrough curves were determined using a 10 mgN.l-1 threshold 189 
effluent concentration (US regulatory limit). Breakthrough curves (1 to 6) were run to 190 
complete exhaustion initially using freshly produced regenerant (Brinefp, 50gNaCl.l-1, 191 
Figure 6(a)). The threshold was reached at c.400 bed volumes (BVs) in the second run 192 
which corresponded to a resin capacity of 0.61 eq.l-1 or 88% of throughput obtained 193 
with the virgin resin during the first run. Subsequent runs 3 to 6 indicated a near 194 
identical trend demonstrating reproducible regeneration efficiency under these 195 
conditions. A capacity of c.0.46 eq.l-1 has been observed previously by Bae et al. 196 
(2002) using the same commercially available resin (A520E); the lower capacity may 197 
be explained by the authors’ application of a lower strength regenerant (30gNaCl.l-1). 198 
 199 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
9 
 
Breakthrough curves (1-6) were subsequently generated with fresh resin using 200 
biologically treated brine (Brinebt, 50gNaCl.l-1) as the regenerant (Figure 6(b)). 201 
Brinebt was sampled from the MBR permeate once steady state had been reached 202 
during permeate recirculation. At steady state, the DOC concentration of the brinebt 203 
was c.287 mg.l-1. Under these conditions, breakthrough occurred at c.390 BVs in the 204 
second run, corresponding to 0.58 eq.l-1 or 87% of throughput obtained with the virgin 205 
resin during the first run. Comparison with Run 4 (a) using brinefp (Figure 6(b)) 206 
demonstrated a loss in capacity (Area 1) indicating the extent of interference created 207 
by the biologically derived organics. Integration of the area between the brinefp and 208 
brinebt exhaustion curves recorded a capacity loss of 59 meq.l-1 or c.6.5% of the 209 
estimated exhaustive resin capacity.  Bae et al. (2002) observed significant capacity 210 
losses when using permeate from an upflow sludge blanket reactor (USBR) for 211 
regeneration unless subsequent treatment steps were incorporated. However, in this 212 
study subsequent regenerations using brinebt displayed a similar reproducibility 213 
indicating that the resin had reached a maximum organic capacity at the end of the 214 
first regeneration cycle.  215 
 216 
The uptake of brinebt organics by the resin was quantified using a virgin salt saturated 217 
resin (Figure 7). Brine regenerant was assumed to exit the column once chloride 218 
transmission reached 100% (assuming chloride uptake to be zero at saturation). 219 
Chloride and protein transmission reached 100% simultaneously between 1 and 1.5 220 
BVs indicating protein adsorption to be negligible. Polysaccharide and DOC 221 
transmission were recorded at c.15% and c.90% respectively up to 4 BVs, where a 222 
rapid increase in transmission in the interval between 4 and 7 BVs was observed. At 7 223 
BVs, polysaccharide and DOC transmission reached 100%, indicating saturation of 224 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
10 
 
the resin with polysaccharide. Total adsorbed DOC on the 120g resin bed was 225 
estimated at 26.4 mg (0.22 mgDOC.gResin). During exhaustion/regeneration cycles 226 
(Figure 6(b)), the adsorptive mechanism of the polysaccharides was evaluated by 227 
regenerating the resin with a 50/50 fresh brine/biological regenerant (Run 5) and 228 
100% fresh brine (Run 6). The similarity of the subsequent exhaustion curves 229 
suggested low polysaccharide exchange potential (i.e. reversibility).  230 
 231 
3.4 Salt shocking 232 
To reflect the significant salt variations occurring in brine regenerant waste, the 233 
regenerant was initially upshocked to 75 gNaCl.l-1 which was subsequently further 234 
increased to 100 gNaCl.l-1 after 7 days. Following the initial upshock (75 gNaCl l-1), 235 
nitrate removal decreased from 99.7 to 60.1% (Table 1) demonstrating a decrease in 236 
the specific biomass denitrification capacity. Protein release was also recorded with 237 
an increase in bulk phase concentration from c.30 to c.50 mg.l-1 and from c.15 to c.30 238 
mg.l-1 following salt upshock to 75 and 100 gNaCl.l-1 respectively (Figure 8). A 239 
transition in floc structure also occurred; at steady state (50 gNaCl.l-1), a floc size 240 
distribution ranging 60 to 800μm was measured, however, following upshocking to 241 
75 gNaCl.l-1, a bi-modal distribution was recorded with the dominant peak ranging 242 
0.2 to 5μm, indicating floc breakage into primary particles (Wilén et al., 2003). After 243 
7 days at 100gNaCl.l-1, the system was downshocked to 50 gNaCl.l-1; sampling 24 244 
hours after downshocking demonstrated near complete denitrification recovery to 245 
98.4%.   246 
 247 
Although the volume of particulate and colloidal material had apparently increased, 248 
critical flux analysis conducted before and after each salt increment (Figure 9) 249 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
11 
 
indicated that fouling propensity remained stable as demonstrated by the similar dP/dt 250 
trends obtained. In addition, Jc was consistently recorded at c.12 l.m-2.h-1 and is 251 
comparable to that recorded during steady-state recirculation. This contradicts a 252 
previous non-halophilic MBR study where upon exposure to a 5 g.l-1 chloride residual 253 
(0.83% NaCl) both protein and polysaccharide were released causing permeability 254 
decline (flat sheet, 0.4 μm) which was correlated to the elevated SMP polysaccharide 255 
concentration (Reid et al., 2006); the absence of elevated concentrations of secreted 256 
polysaccharide in this current study may in part explain this disparity.  257 
 258 
Twenty PLFA fatty acid methyl esters (FAMES), identified by MS, principally 259 
comprised normal saturates and terminally branched saturates.  Trans-monoenoic fatty 260 
acid concentrations were below the limit of detection. Dominant FAMES were C16:0, 261 
C16:1, C17:0, C18, C18:1ω9c and C19:0cy at 50, 75 and 100 gNaCl.l-1 and accounted 262 
for c.95% of PLFAs detected (Table 2). Similar elution profiles (and the absence of 263 
trans-monoenoic fatty acids) were observed previously for a range of moderately and 264 
extremely halophilic bacterium (Aston and Peyton, 2007; Yakimov et al., 2001). 265 
Principal component analysis (PCA) showed three discrete data groupings 266 
corresponding to salt concentration (Figure 10). Analysis of variance of the principal 267 
components (PC) confirmed significant differences of P<0.001 and P<0.01 for 268 
principal components PC1 and PC2 respectively. This distinction indicates abrupt 269 
changes in phenotypic profile between step changes in salinity.  270 
 271 
4. DISCUSSION 272 
4.1 MBR Fouling 273 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
12 
 
High polysaccharide transmission of c.81.5% was observed during steady state due to 274 
the production of low MW biopolymers and corresponded to a mean DOC removal of 275 
c.44%. Low MW biopolymers are generally associated with substrate metabolism and 276 
biomass growth (Barker et al., 2000) and are produced in all MBR applications. Using 277 
LC-OCD, Zhang et al. (2006) observed 99.8% high MW (c.250 kDa) and 93.6% low 278 
MW (5 to 250 kDa) biopolymer rejection when using a 0.2 µm flat sheet membrane in 279 
an MBR and cited polysaccharide as the major foulant. The authors suggested this 280 
behaviour to be a common trait of fouled MF membranes; improved retention of low 281 
MW biopolymers (and higher dP/dt) in their investigation may arise from more 282 
significant internal deposition created by the larger pore size. In this study, 283 
concentration (accumulation) of low MW biopolymers in the bulk phase by permeate 284 
recirculation did not increase fouling propensity. This indicates that: (1) low MW 285 
biopolymers asserted poor aggregation potential upon recirculation and thus were not 286 
filtered; and (2) biopolymers exhibited limited binding potential to the membrane 287 
surface and any biofilm present. This contradicts previous experiences with 288 
polysaccharides (Zhang et al., 2006; Frank and Belfort, 2003), however, past research 289 
has typically focused on high MW polysaccharides (100 to 1600 kDa) which possess 290 
more structural and functional complexity than those of lower MW biopolymers 291 
(48.3% below 10 kDa) as in this study; higher MW structures may thus concentrate at 292 
the membrane surface by both size exclusion and surface adhesion (Frank and Belfort, 293 
2003). 294 
 295 
Fouling propensity was not greatly increased by salt shocking. The characteristic 296 
response of non-halophilic micro-organisms exposed to salt upshock is to undergo 297 
plasmolysis due to a loss in turgor pressure (Reid et al., 2006). This induces the 298 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
13 
 
release of soluble cellular components through the cell membrane (Laspidou and 299 
Rittmann, 2002) and in some instances the subsequent release of cell wall components 300 
such as acid mucopolysaccharides, resulting in high concentrations of proteins and 301 
polysaccharides in the bulk phase (Reid et al., 2006, Zhang et al., 2006). In this study, 302 
only protein was released, implying that cell lysis did not occur. Halophilic bacteria 303 
possess modified highly negatively charged proteins on the external cell wall to 304 
mediate osmotic shifts (Petrovic et al., 1999); the protein release observed may 305 
therefore have been an adjustment in cell wall composition (Russell, 1989). In 306 
addition, cell wall modification may have initiated the floc destabilisation observed 307 
upon upshocking causing indirect release of extracellular protein from the floc matrix 308 
as postulated by Reid et al. (2006). The absence of secreted polysaccharide, structure 309 
and size distribution of the organics produced by halophilic bacteria and the lower 310 
membrane pore size adopted in this investigation (0.04 µm, potentially limiting 311 
internal deposition) may explain the disparity in organics rejection and fouling 312 
compared to previous literature findings (Reid et al., 2006; Zhang et al., 2006). 313 
 314 
4.2 Microbial community and treatment performance 315 
PLFA profiles were dominated by a small range of fatty acids that are common 316 
amongst halophiles (Aston and Peyton, 2007; Yakimov et al., 2001). The trans/cis 317 
ratio was consistently <0.15 at all three salt concentrations indicating that the cell 318 
membrane remained stable - a ratio above 0.25 indicating instability (Aston and 319 
Peyton, 2007) - further suggesting that plasmolysis did not occur. Transition of PLFA 320 
profiles at each salt increment indicated reordering of the membrane lipid 321 
composition for osmoregulation (Russell, 1989; Pflüger and Muller, 2004) and 322 
microbial community restructuring (Forney et al., 2001) as described previously for 323 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
14 
 
salt upshocking of denitrifying halophiles (Yoshie et al., 2006). The decrease in 324 
nitrate removal from 99.7% to between 58.6% and 73.6% may therefore be due to 325 
microbial restructuring, however, lower specific bacterial growth rates have been 326 
observed at high salt concentrations. Peyton et al. (2001) established that Halomonas 327 
campisalis could effectively denitrify at 180 gNaCl.l-1 (Peyton et al., 2001), though 328 
the maximum specific growth rate for the monoculture was identified at c.30gNaCl.l-1 329 
(Aston and Peyton, 2007). In this study, upon down shocking to 50gNaCl.l-1 330 
denitrification capacity recovered to 98.4% within 24 hours. This demonstrates that 331 
whilst transition in community structure occurred following salt upshocking, an 332 
effective residual halotolerant denitrifying community remained following 333 
perturbation; extension of SRT (>10 days) may be sufficient to offset the lower 334 
growth rates observed at high salt concentrations.    335 
 336 
4.3 Resin operation 337 
It has been suggested that polysaccharides do not normally deposit easily onto aIEX 338 
resin due to impeded diffusion (by size exclusion) and low contact times (Cornelissen 339 
et al., 2008). In this study, polysaccharides contacted the resin during regeneration 340 
rather than exhaustion, thus increasing contact time by a factor of four. Adsorption of 341 
exopolysaccharides to anionic resins is intuitive as their structure is principally 342 
polyanionic due to the number of uronic acid or ketal linked pyruvate groups 343 
contained within the long chain high MW (500-2000 kDa) structures (Sutherland, 344 
2001). However, based on the low affinity shown for desorption of polysaccharides in 345 
this study, it appears that the dominant adsorption mechanism associated with the 346 
lower MW polysaccharides present in the brine is physical rather than exchange 347 
based. DOC uptake could not be quantified during exhaustion runs due to competition 348 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
15 
 
effects with the influent DOC. Therefore, based on physical data, the theoretical 349 
charge density (approximated by normalising lost resin capacity with DOC uptake, 350 
Figure 7) was c.3.9x10-4 meq.gDOC-1; this negligible result further demonstrates that 351 
adsorption was not exchange based and indicates that the adsorbed organics exhibited 352 
a charge closer to neutrality. Kim and Symons (1991) postulated that physical 353 
adsorption was more likely to occur at the resin skeleton. After the first regeneration 354 
with brinebt, physical adsorption reached a maximum, presumably due to the limited 355 
number of adsorption sites available.  356 
 357 
5. CONCLUSIONS 358 
A study of the denitrification of high salinity ion exchange brine regenerant and the 359 
impact of accumulation on process performance has demonstrated recycling for ion 360 
exchange regeneration to be viable. 361 
1. Whilst recirculation generated high concentrations of low MW organics, their 362 
impact on membrane permeability was negligible. 363 
2. Although salt upshock induced protein release, the permeability decline was 364 
minimal, contrary to previous studies based on non-halophilic communities. 365 
3. Nitrate removal of c.99.7% was observed at steady-state (50 gNaCl.l-1); at salt 366 
concentrations above 50 gNaCl.l-1 nitrate removal decreased and the 367 
community profile was modified, though this could be countered by adoption 368 
of a higher SRT to offset the lower growth rates.  369 
4. Adsorption of the low MW organics generated during denitrification onto the 370 
resin structure resulted in minimal loss in resin capacity, implying long-term 371 
operation using recovered brine is possible. 372 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ARTICLE IN PRESS
16 
 
5. Under halophilic conditions, addition of exogenous substrate must be 373 
controlled to minimise breakthrough and to support complete denitrification 374 
(limiting the preferential formation of nitrite). 375 
6. The efficacy of the denitrification MBR process is closely related to 376 
membrane rejection and the structural and functional attributes of the resultant 377 
organics; both the process operational determinants and the bacterial 378 
community generated may influence performance.  379
